skill.name: terraform-module-library
skill.description: Build reusable Terraform modules for AWS, Azure, and GCP infrastructure following infrastructure-as-code best practices. Use when creating infrastructure modules, standardizing cloud provisioning, or implementing reusable IaC components.
skill.summary: Build reusable Terraform modules for AWS, Azure, and GCP infrastructure following infrastructure-as-...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files with Terraform patterns and examples. No executable code (.tf, .go, .sh files present). Static findings are all false positives triggered by documentation text patterns (Terraform resource names, module paths, example CIDR blocks). Content matches stated purpose of providing IaC guidance.

content.value_statement: Teams struggle to standardize Terraform modules across clouds. This skill provides patterns, examples, and testing guidance to create reusable infrastructure modules.
actual_capabilities: Defines a standard Terraform module folder structure with main, variables, outputs, and tests
Provides an AWS VPC module example with subnets, internet gateway, and tags
Shows module composition patterns for connecting VPC and RDS modules
Documents a Terratest example for validating module outputs
Lists AWS module patterns for EKS, RDS, S3, ALB, Lambda, and security groups
limitations: Does not include runnable module code assets in this directory
Azure and GCP reference files are not present in this version
Does not automate deployment, testing, or module publishing

use_cases.title: Standardize AWS modules
use_cases.description: Create consistent Terraform module structures and examples for shared AWS infrastructure across teams.

use_cases.title: Define module standards
use_cases.description: Set documentation, testing, and versioning conventions for reusable Terraform modules organization-wide.

use_cases.title: Design module composition
use_cases.description: Plan how VPC, database, and compute modules connect to form complete environments.

prompt_templates.title: Start a module layout
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a standard Terraform module folder structure for an AWS VPC module including examples and tests.

prompt_templates.title: Define module inputs
prompt_templates.prompt: List required and optional variables for an AWS VPC module with validation guidance for CIDR blocks.

prompt_templates.title: Add testing guidance
prompt_templates.prompt: Outline a Terratest plan for a VPC module including key assertions for VPC ID and subnet outputs.

prompt_templates.title: Compose multiple modules
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to compose VPC and RDS modules with shared tags and cross-module outputs for production.

output_examples.input: Create a reusable AWS VPC module plan
output: Module layout with main.tf, variables.tf, outputs.tf, versions.tf, examples/, and tests/
Key variables: name, cidr_block, availability_zones, private_subnet_cidrs with validation
Essential outputs: vpc_id, private_subnet_ids, vpc_cidr_block for composition
Testing checklist using Terratest with assertions for VPC ID presence and CIDR validation
Use semantic versioning and pin provider versions for consistency
Document all inputs and outputs with clear descriptions for consumers
Include working examples showing how to invoke each module
Add Terratest cases covering happy path and edge cases

best_practices: Document all inputs and outputs with clear descriptions for module consumers
Use semantic versioning and pin provider versions in versions.tf
Include working example configurations and automated tests with Terratest
anti_patterns: Embedding environment-specific values like account IDs or region directly in module code
Omitting input validation for critical variables like CIDR blocks or instance sizes
Publishing modules without example usage showing how to invoke them

faq.question: Is this compatible with my Terraform version?
faq.answer: Guidance aligns with Terraform 1.x and AWS provider 5.x. Check your provider constraints for compatibility.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: This skill provides patterns and examples only. It does not ship runnable modules or deployment automation.

faq.question: How do I integrate this into my repo?
faq.answer: Adopt the module structure and copy patterns into your module directories and documentation files.

faq.question: Does it access or store my data?
faq.answer: No. It is documentation content without any data access, file system operations, or network activity.

faq.question: What if module tests fail?
faq.answer: Check variable defaults, provider configuration, and example inputs. Ensure Terraform and providers are installed correctly.

faq.question: How does it compare to Terraform Registry modules?
faq.answer: This focuses on patterns and structure for building your own modules. Registries provide ready-made modules you can consume directly.
